data.title: Commemorating 50 Years
data.meta_description: Commemorating 50 years of Resilience, Growth and Purpose, So Every Generation Prospers.
data.text:
âThere were just six of us, and everyone attended all the meetings. Junior members like me could listen in when our bosses talked about strategies and partner dynamics, and we learnt from the best.â As Temasek became an active investor, first regionally and then globally, the team was responsible for introducing Temasek to the outside world. âWe had to go out there to these global funds and explain who we were, what we did, and the connections we could help them make,â she says. âIf people didn't know anything about you, why would they do business with you? How could they trust you?â

Over time, the companyâs external narrative matured, taking shape in the first Temasek Review â a public report of its portfolio performance â published in 2004. The same year, Temasek earned triple-A credit ratings from S&P and Moodyâs for the quality of its portfolio.

âTo me, that made it real,â says Ming Pey. âIâd spent years explaining our commercial operations and telling funds and companies why they would want us as an investor. Now there were these public markers recognising Temasekâs commitment to transparency and accountability, and reporting on the portfolio and performance we had achieved.â

The years that followed were hectic as the pace of investment picked up, she remembers. By 2005, there were various sector-focused investment teams within Temasek, and the company had offices in Mumbai, Beijing and Shanghai. By this time, Ming Pey had joined the Direct Investment team, covering sectors such as Technology and Financial Services. âWe were growing the portfolio and doing deals very quickly. I remember it coincided with the launch of the BlackBerry device â suddenly, everyone could work anytime, anywhere, and many of us â and our bosses â were online almost 24/7,â she says.

Writing the next chapter

As the company grew and more investment staff came on board, Temasekâs âDNAâ evolved. âWe used to operate in a small, cosy and family-like environment where everyone knew and took care of one another. But over time, the environment became more professional, and the focus shifted to achieving performance and delivering results.â

It was a shift that Ming Pey noted and voiced out to the then-head of HR Sebastian Tan.

âI asked him what kind of organisation we wanted to build â did we want to maintain a caring and nurturing environment, or push for a high performance and returns-oriented culture,â she recalls. âHe asked me why the two could not co-exist, and then put down a challenge: if I felt so strongly about it, then I should do something to make it so. I took that as a personal challenge.â When she returned from maternity leave in 2007, Ming Pey joined the Organisation & People team to work on Organisational Development, including projects and initiatives that would ensure Temasek retained its strong sense of purpose and heritage, even as it continued to grow its portfolio and talent pool.

âThis was where I could leverage my familiarity with how Temasek had evolved,â she says. âBy integrating these stories into our internal communications and staff engagement exercises, we could help people understand our purpose and our way of life.â

Things crystallised in 2019 when she became a part of the working team for T2030, a 10-year roadmap for the firm that would guide the building of a resilient and forward looking portfolio in an increasingly complex world. âBut before we could find a way forward, we had to first look back,â she says. One of her first tasks was to compile a âreport cardâ for what the firm had achieved in the decade to 2020.

In the process, she was able to âconnect the dotsâ, and see how the various business and institutional initiatives undertaken by the firm had come together to create the global investment powerhouse that Temasek had become.

The work Temasek does often takes years to play out, she says. âI tell those stories to my juniors so they understand how their decisions today will impact the company in the future. To me, that generational thinking is very important â to know that what I do today, somebody else is going to inherit.

"My hope is that a young employee in the future will look back at all the things we are doing today, and think to themselves, âSo this is what they were trying to achieve for usâ. I hope they value how it all came together, and go on to shape the Temasek that future generations will build on."

Over the course of her 37-year career, Margina had a front-row seat to Temasekâs growth story, as the company expanded its portfolio and grew beyond Singapore to become a global investment powerhouse. She also witnessed several firsts, including Temasekâs first greenfield venture, the Pulau Ayer Merbau Complex, in 1984; the listing of SMRT in 2000 â incidentally, also the first time an urban rail operator had been listed anywhere in the world; the publication of the first Temasek Review and the opening of Temasekâs first overseas office in Mumbai, both in 2004. The same year, she celebrated with her colleagues when Temasek earned a triple-A credit rating from S&P and Moodyâs for the quality of its portfolio.

She moved with the company from the attic office in Fullerton Building to the CPF Building on Robinson Road, and then the Treasury Building at Shenton Way â which was renamed Temasek Tower â before finally settling in at its current premises at The Atrium@Orchard in Dhoby Ghaut in 2002.

As the scope of her job grew, Margina completed a company-sponsored diploma in Management Accounting & Finance, and as technology redefined the workplace, she acquired her first cell phone and computer skills.

By the time she retired in December 2014, Margina was Senior Associate in a Finance department that had expanded from two to over 50. Temasek itself had grown from the initial four staff members and portfolio of 35 Singapore companies, to a staff of 490 and more than 250 portfolio companies as of 31 March 2014. By then, it also had overseas offices in seven countries.

As she looks back on how far Temasek has come since she set foot into that Fullerton Building attic all those years ago, she is proud. But what she is most grateful for are the friendships that have endured.

âTemasek was a big part of my life. It was where I built my career and found my best friendsâ¦ it will always feel like family.â

Most days, Lim Ah Lee can be found by the window of Ward 2A, glued to the news on his Lexon radio. Other days, the longtime Surya Nursing Home resident hums along with the Mandarin classics playing on his constant companion and âbest friendâ.

To most, the radio has seen better days. But to the still-sharp 88-year-old, the small brown box connects him to the world.

âDid you know the temple on Kusu Island is now 100 years old?â he asks. âI heard it on my radio.â

âUncleâ Ah Lee tells anyone who will listen how he won the radio in a bingo game organised by Temasek some two decades ago.

âââAt the time, the former leprosy sufferer was a charge of the Singapore Leprosy Relief Association (SILRA), the very first home adopted by Temasek under its T-Touch initiative in early 2002. The firm had decided then that giving should be a cornerstone of its culture, and through T-Touch, it could support staff-led volunteer initiatives and encourage volunteerism.

In those days, SILRA had about 90 residents. Like Uncle Ah Lee, many had spent decades living in the home. The stigma associated with leprosy meant visitors and volunteers were hard to come by, despite the fact that a cure for the disease had been available in Singapore since the 1950s. Many bore physical scars of the disease, but loneliness often felt like the worst one.

That was precisely why, when put to a company-wide vote, Temasek chose SILRA â it was where they were most needed. Their visits became a high point, providing the companionship and acceptance the residents craved.

When SILRA was absorbed by Sunlove Home in 2018 and the building renamed Surya Nursing Home, the tradition continued: no festival goes by forgotten, and familiar faces regularly come by bearing ang pows, mooncakes and other treats, and stay to chat. âWe are always happy to see themâ¦ Every time Temasek comes, they bring a nice buffet. There was a pasar malam one time, and there is always bingo,â says Uncle Ah Lee.

He remembers the exact game in which the radio came to be his. It hadnât been going terribly well. âI think the volunteer covering the numbers for me kelong (rigged it), but I won the last radio,â he laughs.

A search for white spaces

Part of the groupâs mandate was to identify and invest in innovative technologies with the potential to drive the planet closer towards climate resilience, and Temasek towards a net-zero portfolio.

âGiven the scale of the sustainability crisis, we didnât know where to start,â Immanuâel recalls.

The team cast its net wide, exploring everything from sustainable aviation fuels to nuclear fusion, attempting to uncover white spaces that could be explored, whether now or in the future.

He remembers then-CEO Ho Ching addressing him during one of their meetings. âI was the youngest one in the team then, and she said that we needed more young people in our team because it was going to be up to my generation â and the ones that came after us â to take the possibilities of nuclear energy forward.

âI realised then that this was going to be a multi-decade-commitment, with an enormous potential for being a force for good.â

The teamâs first task was to put in place a robust framework that could guide both investment and strategic decisions. âThis levelled everyone up so we could drive the changes the world needed to see in a dedicated and measured way,â he says.

Immanuâel himself trained his focus on decarbonisation, and within that, low carbon hydrogen, a topic close to his heart. He animatedly explains how low carbon hydrogen is a critical part of Singaporeâs future energy mix, given its limited access to renewable energy.

âWe searched for under-addressed challenges and for potential solutions and policies that the firm could consider in its choice of investments. We had to think about why no one had solved them, and if they had tried and failed, then where the pitfalls lay.

âWe went from problem to solution, then reverse-engineered our way back to better defining the problem. It was an iterative process.â

Impact, for generations

As the headlines around sustainability evolved over the years, so did the mandate of the Sustainability Group. It now comprises three sub-groups overseeing Sustainability & Climate Change Strategy, Ecosperity, a platform for engagement and advocacy, and Sustainable Solutions, which Immanuâel heads.

His focus is on solutions that could have a direct impact on Temasek and its portfolio companies. Immanuâel also doubles up as a Director of Emerging Technologies, which looks further into the future, at nascent deep-tech ideas that, with the right support â including from companies like Temasek â could evolve into commercially viable technologies with the potential to make a big difference.

âThe challenge is that these technologies are almost always very new. Some of them may not exist at any sort of scale yet, and of those that do exist, some may not succeed. You have to scientifically and systematically predict if itâs going to work, how that might impact our businesses, and if that impact will be long term.

âThat said, Temasek is in the business of looking around the bend, so you never get bored,â he says.

It is quite a change from what he envisioned himself doing, Immanuâel admits. In finance, âcurrencyâ is viewed solely in terms of returns, risks and time dimensions. Today, his focus is on how money translates into value, not just in the immediate future, but for future generations.

âThe idea of being in a company that is only interested in profit now feels empty. The pre-Temasek Immanuâel might have been okay with that, but not anymore,â he says. âIâve seen how Temasek puts time, money, commitment and people into bringing real value to communities, now and in the future.

âIâve been infused with its DNA â and now Iâm hooked.â

It was intended as a âheads-upâ on a developing trend, says Franziska Zimmermann.

It was January 2019, during the annual âT-Huddleâ â Temasekâs leadership summit â that the Director of Sustainability & Climate Change Strategy made her presentation. âInvestors were increasingly being held accountable for the carbon emissions associated with their investment portfolios,â she says. âWe wanted to brief senior management on this development.â

Instead, her presentation sparked an unprecedented decision: to target a 50% reduction in the net carbon emissions attributable to Temasekâs investment portfolio by 2030, compared to 2010 levels, and achieve net zero emissions by 2050.

âWe didnât know yet how we would achieve this,â Franziska recalls, âbutâ we knew that this was where we needed to get to.â â

The decision marked a significant shift. âWe werenât just committing to a target; we were sending a powerful signal, both internally and externally.â

Putting the planet in focus

Sustainability has been a consistent theme in Franziskaâs life.

âI was born on Earth Day, so I guess you could say itâs a calling,â she laughs. Growing up in a small Swiss village, Franziska spent her days roaming the surrounding forests. âYou learn what the environment means, how it relates to you, your community, and your survival.â Her teenage years, marked by environmental catastrophes close to home â Chernobyl, chemical spills, and acid rain â underscored these critical lessons.

As a law student, she did her Masterâs thesis on environmental sustainability, and it remained a common thread in a career that spanned public and private-sector companies across Europe and Asia. âI felt it was something worth fighting for,â she says.

Franziska joined Temasekâs Strategic and Public Affairs team in 2015, coincidentally, the year the Paris Agreement â the global pact to curb climate change â was signed. Temasek was growing its presence in Europe and was looking for someone who could translate policy into business impact. Responsible investing was gaining traction at the time, she says. âI remember my then-boss, Gary Ang saying to me: âWell Franziska, youâre passionate about the environment, why don't you look at whether this is something we should be tracking more closelyâ.â

âI did my research, spoke to people, and began sending updates to senior management and the organisation whenever there was a development in the sustainability and climate space,â she recalls. She also took charge of Ecosperity, then a half-day conference that brought Temasekâs portfolio companies together to advance the twinning of environmental sustainability with economic development.

The 2016 haze added impetus to Temasekâs sustainability initiatives. As forests in Indonesia burned, Singapore grappled with the health and economic impacts, prompting intense media scrutiny on investors backing the companies responsible. While Temasek was not involved, the crisis led to a reassessment of potential risks within its investments. "We needed to consider the types of businesses we wanted to invest in and establish clear boundaries,â says Franziska.

The realisation that sustainability needed to be a core consideration in evaluating investment opportunities led to the establishment of a project team to develop the frameworks to enable this.

âWe co-developed the frameworks with the investment teams to strike the right balance between rigour and practicalityââââââ,â she recalls. By 2017, the frameworks had been integrated internally and communicated externally, solidifying sustainability as a permanent feature within the organisation.

Meanwhile, Temasek was advancing several other key initiatives. In 2017, it established a sustainability team to test and mainstream sustainability strategies, investments and solutions within the company. A dedicated decarbonisation-focused investment platform, incubated by the team, would later be spun off as GenZero, with a mandate to accelerate decarbonisation through strategic investments and partnerships. Over the years, Ecosperity had also expanded into a global sustainability conference, attracting prominent leaders from the public and non-governmental sectors, captains of industry, and the academic community. The week-long conference engages participants in collaborative efforts to tackle the ongoing climate crisis and promote sustainable growth across Asia.

âIt was a sign of maturity, of Temasek recognising that its influence extended beyond investing money, and that its voice, perspective, and convening power mattered and could make a difference,â says Franziska.

ââBy this timeâ, âTemasekâsâ Sustainabilityâ andâ âStewardship âGroup, âfirst announced in 2016, had gained visibility and traction as a âdepartment in its own right. âThis paved the way for us to bring together all these organic initiatives into a cohesive strategy.â

Ultimately, it laid the groundwork for Franziskaâs presentation at the T-Huddle in January 2019, and Temasekâs bold commitment.

Making good on green ambitions

Looking back, Franziska is struck by how far Temasek has come in just a decade. For two consecutive years, in 2023 and 2024, the company was recognised by the Global Sovereign Fund as a leader in governance and sustainability. In 2024, it also released its inaugural sustainability report, sharing its goals, practices and performance with the aim of fostering trust and engaging in meaningful dialogue on the topic with key stakeholders.

âSustainability is at the core of everything we do, and one of four strategic pillars of our T2030 10-year strategy,â she says. The cultural shift permeates all levels of the organisation, influencing daily operations and long-term planning. âEvery leader within the organisation considers how they can contribute within their area of responsibility. Weâve come a long way.â

âWe know that to be successful as an investor, we have to operate in an environment thatâs healthy, where nature is intact and society thrives. Seeing our organisation boldly commit to that has been truly gratifying.â

From passion to profession

The year 2018 marked a turning point for Yvonne. Taking a course on Politics, Business and the Common Good in the UK, she was struck by a question posed by her professor. âIf you're rethinking your career,â he challenged, âwhat about ensuring you do good while you make a living?â

After 15 years in the fast-paced world of commercial television with Fox International Channels, âit was a eureka moment,â she says. Volunteering had been a consistent part of her life, but the possibility of integrating social impact into her â9 to 6â had never truly occurred.

Serendipitously, she learned about Temasek Trust and its nascent social impact hub. âThe drawings for Temasek Shophouse were underway, and they were looking for someone to head the project,â she recalls. A two-hour conversation with then-CEO, Cheo Hock Kuan, had her firmly on board.

The idea was to bring changemakers under the same roof, and provide a space â and opportunities â for collaboration, co-working, and knowledge exchange, she says. To that end, Temasek Shophouse would house Temasek Trust, Temasek Foundation, and Stewardship Asia, as well as coworking partners like Asia-focused impact investor. Other spaces would allow people passionate about giving back to meet, host events or workshops, and draw in the public. Ultimately, it aspired to be the foundation for an ecosystem centred around social impact.

âIn 2018, a social impact hub was still a novel concept. No one really knew how to take that idea and make it come alive,â she says. âWere we a co-working space? Another community centre? We also had to think of the kind of tenants and events we wanted to bring in.â These needed to be aligned with the Shophouseâs mission.

âI remember going to meet the owners of Foreword Coffee,â she says. â I had to wait for an hour, but it was an interesting hour observing how they put differently-abled people on the front lines and taught them so patiently. I knew even before speaking to them that they were the right people to invite into our space.â

The team also experimented with promoting biodiversity, including rehousing a beehive found in Mandai on the Shophouseâs rooftop, and creating a ten-metre-high Art Deco-inspired âgreen wallâ that forms its centrepiece.

âI remember wondering at one point whether we had bitten off more than we could chew,â she laughs. "But then I realised that we had to walk the talk and integrate our values into every aspect of the Shophouse.

It began without any fanfare; just a familiar name quietly appearing on social media platforms, first Twitter â now X â then Facebook. Over time, YouTube, Instagram and TikTok âwere also âadded to the list.

âTemasek was no longer a small investment company that could fly under the radar, and social media was not something that could be ignored,â says Stephen Forshaw, then-Head of Public Affairs. âAs the firm grew, more people were paying attention to us, so our communication strategy had to evolve. We decided to tell our story, in our own voice.â

It was the early 2010s, and few corporations had made the leap into social media. Of those who had, some had made more than a few digital stumbles, leaving a trail of awkward interactions and deleted posts in their wake.

Despite this, Temasek remained convinced of both the potential and necessity to engage on social media. It offered a unique opportunity to speak directly to its audience â to tell them who Temasek was and how it pursued its objectives. When the challenge â dubbed Project Nike â was put to the team, they embraced the spirit embodied by the sportswear giantâs tagline to âJust Do Itâ, Stephen recalls. However, the team didnât simply launch from the starting block. They opted for a thoughtful approach, testing ideas and building on what worked.

âWe focused on doing it well,â says Stephen. âWe knew that once we started, there would be no turning back. We would have to continue populating our social media channels with a steady stream of content, and that content had to be interesting and informative.â

A high point came when its growing base of followers began not just commenting on, but sharing its content. âI remember the first time we got a share. There was a bit of excitement,â Stephen says. âIt marked a shift. Our audience was beginning to respond, and even if they were sometimes provocative, they were engaged. To us, it was meaningful, because it was genuine.â

Today, Temasek has over 250,000 followers on its social platforms.

âOne thing Temasek has always been very good at is recognising âquickly âwhen things are changing,â he says. âThe firm identifies trends and acts on them. Thatâs what we did here.â

From âreactive to proactiveâ

Stephen, a veteran communicator who had worked for brands like Singapore Airlines and Microsoft, joined Temasek in 2011. It was a time of massive change â the firm was rapidly growing, both in size and portfolio, and its focus had shifted from emerging Asia to the world.

However, beyond its role as an investor, little was known about Temasek, and that needed to change, he says.

âWe had to make our narrative clear â who we were, what we did, and why. A lot of our media engagement was transaction-based, but there was so much more we could say about what we stood for as a forward-looking institution, and all we did for the communities we worked with as a trusted steward.â

Over the next few years, he built a digital newsroom within Temasek and grew its social media team, which soon included former journalists, visual storytellers, and marketing and analytics professionals. They shaped how Temasek spoke about itself, and worked closely with teams across the firm, from investment and technology to community stewardship and talent development, to develop content that was worth sharing.

As Temasek built its social media presence, it also listened intently â engaging with those who commented, and responding when misinformation was spread.

It was empowering â the firm had a chance to tell stories not just about doing well, but also about how it was doing right and doing good. By the time the 2018 Temasek Review (TR) was launched, it was âsocial firstâ rather than âsocial followsâ, says Stephen.

âWe had videos, photos, infographics, animations, and charts online, all of which helped to bring the Temasek story to life. We achieved more reach than we had ever had. Our audience was taken on a journey that allowed them to not just understand our financial results but the values we embodied and the mission we were driving towards. It was clearly making a difference to what people understood about Temasek.â

Temasek continues to make a concerted effort to take its audience behind the numbers of its annual disclosure exercise, explaining the thinking behind investments, discussing significant trends, and demonstrating the impact of Temasekâs community initiatives.

The power of connection

By the time Stephen left the firm and moved to Australia in 2022, public communication had become a critical part of Temasekâs personality and the way it did business.

âThere will never be a shortage of critics, and criticism is something we should listen to and learn from,â he says. âHowever, weâve created a channel that allows us to engage, ensuring that the public has a greater understanding of what Temasek does and can form its own views, and is reassured that even at the most challenging times, it will step up and support the community in ways that are distinctive and genuine.â

That was apparent in efforts made during crises like the ââ2014 haze and the COVID-19 pandemic, and in its purpose statement, So Every Generation Prospers, which Stephen helped crystallise between 2020 and 2021.

âThese four words embody what Temasek, as a firm, and all its people, stand for. They connect all three pillars of what the firm does into one overriding ambition. Prosperity is about more than just returns. It's about sustainability, community health, living standards, social cohesiveness, and leaving no one behind. It reinforces the notion that social prosperity is on par with financial prosperity. What Temasek does has real meaning, both financially and for communities.â

This is a story Stephen hopes Temasek will keep telling.

âDemystifying an organisation like Temasek does not happen overnight. It takes constant engagement, strong storytelling and being open about what Temasek does. Itâs a journey â and one I was really happy to be a part of.

Mark Lim may be Temasek's Chief Digital Officer, but catch him in a free moment and heâs more likely to be engrossed in a video about behavioural science than fancy algorithms.

âDigital transformation is as much about people as it is about technology,â he says. âHowever sophisticated or innovative a tech tool might be, itâs of no use if people donât use it or if it doesnât solve their problems.â

Championing user needs has been a driving force for Mark since he co-founded the Government Digital Services (GDS) department of the then-Infocomm Development Authority in 2010. There, he drew on software development strategies more typical of tech giants like Apple and Meta to fundamentally change how people interacted with the government.

His teamâs progressive approach resulted in the quick and successful deployment of many citizen-facing web and mobile apps, such as the national digital identity app SingPass Mobile, the community first responders app MyResponder, and the first National Library Board app, among others. It attracted Temasekâs attention.

By 2017, Temasek had grown into a global investment powerhouse and was seeking to unlock more possibilities through digital transformation. GDSâ gregarious Director, who passionately advocated for empathetic and data-driven design, and automation for software testing, seemed the right person to to lead it.

Transformation, scaled

Mark moved to Temasek at the start of 2018, with a mandate to empower its teams through the use of the âtriple Aâ â automation, analytics and AI.

The 2010s had witnessed a massive digital tidal wave sweep the globe, fuelled by the convergence of 4G networks and cloud computing, empowering organisations with the infrastructure they needed to innovate and scale. Meanwhile, the mobile revolution had put user-centric design in the spotlight, paving the way for disruptive AI and Big Data to revolutionise business operations and human interactions. For Temasek, the challenge lay in effectively integrating these advancements into its existing workflow.

Mark and his team of three started by conversing with their colleagues across various job functions, to get a comprehensive understanding of the firmâs investment, talent management, and communication needs before considering what needed to be kept, bought, or built.

They then turned their attention to scaling Temasekâs secure cloud platform to enable innovation, and harnessing the potential of data lakes for analytics, collaboration, and data-driven decision-making. They also began rapidly scaling up digital applications and automation tools that would help free up their colleagues from manual âlegworkâ, allowing them to focus on âbrain workâ instead, explains Mark.

Complex as the task was, his approachability and knack for translating complex ideas into relatable concepts helped get various teams on the same page.

For instance, he is a strong proponent of what he calls the kueh lapis (layer cake) approach, breaking complex technology builds into smaller layers, testing and making adjustments along the way to ensure the final product is secure and serves its purpose âdeliciouslyâ.

That was how Winnow, an internal investment platform key to Temasekâs digital infrastructure, was developed â and continues to evolve.

The âsuper appâ, which borrows its name from the agricultural process where chaff is blown away to yield valuable grain, similarly gleans high-quality internal and external data, insights and intelligence on the investments Temasek is considering, including ESG â or Environmental, Social and Governance â factors. Winnow enables Temasekâs global teams to make faster, better-informed and more meaningful decisions.

âFrom the start, we had daily âscreen reviewsâ â a stand-up meeting with investment teams, identifying the right workflows and solutions, and then building them in. Issues were addressed and features were added along the way.

âThatâs why the adoption rate is so high. Weâve built it together, ground up, and we all own it. It solves problems, adds value, and most importantly, itâs a platform they love to use,â he says. As importantly, the iterative process helped foster trust and break down human-technology silos.

And when Temasekâs workforce came to include AI-driven digital âemployeesâ, they all got names. âI wanted people to feel like they were a part of the team. I remind them if they bump into Heidi or Bobby in the pantry, to please be nice and not discriminate against automation,â he laughs.

Fostering a culture of transformation

The first Community Day Huang Zijuan volunteered for, the skies opened up.

âIt was pouring,â recalls Temasekâs Director, Investment (Life Sciences), now a committee member of the staff-led volunteering initiative, T-Touch. Still, the carnival organised in June 2010 at Mindsville@Napiri, a facility for persons with learning disabilities, went off without a hitch. âEveryone just chipped in to do whatever it tookâ¦ we were all quite spent by the end of the day,â she laughs.

Community Day, held annually to mark the anniversary of Temasekâs incorporation on June 25, 1974, is one of dozens of T-Touch volunteer programmes Zijuan has been involved in, and one of hundreds driven by Temasek staff around the world â individually, in groups, and company-wide.

âIn every country that Temasek has an office, T-Touch is very much part of who we are,â she says. âWe want to make a difference to the communities we work in.â

âEach one of us plays a small part. When everything comes together and you look at it as a whole, it's pretty impressive.â

No one left behind

A Temasek scholar, Zijuanâs Involvement in T-Touch began soon after she joined the company in 2006, and deepened through her 18-year career. âI just found myself at a meeting and never left,â she laughs.

An associate with the financial services team, Zijuan moved to the life sciences team in 2011, and then to the Enterprise Development Group in 2013, where she focused on building businesses in the life sciences space, including healthcare platform Sheares Healthcare. In April this year, she rejoined the life sciences team, covering platform companies including ClavystBio, a life sciences investor and venture builder.

âTemasek has always prioritised transparency and credibility,â he says. âWhen restrictions tightened, and regulatory scrutiny increased globally in the mid-2010s, we saw a need for dedicated teams that could anticipate and understand the implications of geopolitical risks and policy developments on investment activities.â
